TEXT: The applicants , Denho Ay and PERSON , a married couple born in DATE and DATE , respectively , are NORP citizens residing in GPE in GPE . Before the ORG they are represented by Mr PERSON , a legal advisor practising in GPE .
The applicants entered GPE in DATE together with their CARDINAL children and applied for asylum .

The first applicant and CARDINAL of the applicants’ children commenced work , whereupon , based on LAW ) in force at the time , they were each obliged to pay , as a surety ( Sicherheit ) for welfare benefits obtained , PERCENT of their salary to a special closed account of ORG ; henceforth ORG ) .

On DATE ORG refused the ORG request for asylum , though they were permitted provisionally to remain in GPE . Upon the applicants’ appeal , ORG ( Asylrekurskommission ) ordered ORG on DATE to accept the applicants as refugees and to grant them asylum . This , ORG did on DATE .

On DATE ORG prepared a final balance ( Abrechnung ) of the CARDINAL closed accounts of the applicants and their CARDINAL children . ORG considered that the amounts of the CARDINAL accounts totalled MONEY ( CHF ) , whereas the applicants had obtained welfare benefits in the amount of CHF CARDINAL . As a result , it informed the applicants that no money could be paid back from the account , though they would only be requested to compensate the outstanding amount of CHF MONEY within the limits of the former LAW of LAW in force at the time .

On DATE the applicants filed an appeal with ORG and Police ( Eidgenössisches Justiz- und NORP , henceforth ORG ) . Therein , and in subsequent submissions , the applicants requested ORG to pay them back the entire amount of the closed surety account . They claimed that their recognition as refugees was declaratory and hence had retroactive character . Thus , their status as refugees extended back to the moment when they entered GPE . The law only required a surety from asylum seekers , i.e. persons applying for the status of refugee , but not from refugees themselves . As the applicants had had refugee status from the outset , the amounts on the surety account should be paid out to them . The applicants also complained , inter alia , of procedural errors and that they had been discriminated against as foreigners .

On DATE ORG prepared a new , amended balance of the CARDINAL closed accounts of the applicants . It considered that the applicants’ children had , at the relevant time , not yet been of age for which reason they were not obliged to pay back the welfare benefits obtained , and they would receive the amounts paid into their closed accounts . In respect of the first applicant , ORG considered that his account contained CHF MONEY and that , after deduction of welfare benefits amounting to CHF CARDINAL , there remained a negative balance of CHF MONEY . The applicants would not , however , be obliged to pay back this amount according to LAW of LAW .

On DATE ORG confirmed that the remaining debt ( ORG ) for the applicants arising from the welfare benefits amounted to CHF MONEY , though this amount would not be collected as long as the applicants had no means and the payment appeared unreasonable .

The applicants’ appeal of CARDINAL DATE was dismissed by ORG on DATE . The decision noted that the applicants were contesting , not a particular amount , but the obligation in principle to pay back the welfare benefits out of the closed account , alleging that their recognition as refugees had retroactive effect . However , the rights under LAW only applied upon recognition of a person as a refugee . The specific obligation for persons applying for asylum to provide for a surety was not affected by the subsequent decision to award refugee status to a person . The decision continued :

“ ( I)t must be emphasised that the lower authority was entitled , regardless of whether the status of asylum was granted , to deduct from the [ first ] applicant ’s surety account a global sum in respect of the welfare benefits obtained both by him and his wife during the asylum proceedings . It will not depend on the applicants’ economic situation whether or not it is admissible to deduct this amount . For this reason , the lower authority did not have to undertake any investigations in this respect . The applicants have not proved lower welfare expenses and indeed do not contest the amounts to be deducted . As a result , the contested decision is lawful and the complaint must be dismissed ... ”

LAW in force at the relevant time provided in Sections CARDINALa § DATE that both refugees and persons applying for such a status , were entitled to welfare benefits if they could not afford to pay for their own subsistence . According to LAW :

“ if the recipient of welfare benefits subsequently obtains means which secure to him and his family an adequate subsistence , he will have to pay back the benefits to the extent that this is reasonable . ”

Section CARDINALa § CARDINAL specifically concerned persons applying for the status of refugee . These persons were obliged , in addition , to provide a surety for future welfare costs . The percentage of the person ’s salary to be paid would be decided by the competent cantonal authority .
In practice , a surety bank account was opened , and the employer of the person concerned would directly transfer the contributions to this account .
In respect of the closing of the account , LAW of LAW no . CARDINAL , GPE , in force at the time ) provided as follows :

CARDINAL . Once the asylum proceedings have been concluded and the applicant ’s residence situation in GPE has been settled by means of a residence permit or a provisional stay , ... ORG [ for Refugees ] shall order the transfer to ORG amounts to be paid back for social security and implementation .

CARDINAL . The ORG shall furthermore order the final balance ( GPE ) and the transfer of any credit to an account mentioned by the applicant . The final balance shall be transmitted to the applicant subject to § CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . If the residence situation of an applicant , who is not a refugee , has been settled by means of a provisional stay , the surety account will remain open . ”
